JTest is nice, but I hadn't realised that it wrote JUnit code? Are you cert=
ain about this?
 
Simon
 
-------------------------------------------------=
----------------
Simon P. Chappell                     simon.chappell@lands=
end.com
Web Developer / Programming Specialist           www.landsend.com
L=
ands' End, Inc.                                   (608) 935-4526


-----Ori=
ginal Message-----
From: andy chang [mailto:andy0126@...]
Sent: Fri=
day, March 15, 2002 10:25 AM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [junit]=
 Is there a tool which generates JUnit-test stubs?


Yes, you should try Jt=
est from ParaSoft.  It will automatically generate harness around the class=
 and stub out any external call.  It will also execute the testcases you wr=
ote using Junit and provide you with a coverage analysis.  In addition, it =
will also generate dynamic test cases for you automatically.  
 

----- Ori=
ginal Message -----
From: markus baumgartner
Sent: Friday, March 15, 2002 8=
:16 AM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [junit] Is there a tool which gen=
erates JUnit-test stubs?
 

I'm spending a lot of time passing new method i=
nto the testclass and write a
"test_" in front of it (and oftenly forget to=
 do it, too).
I made a try to automate the creation of stubs for all existi=
ng methods of a
class using the Reflection API (e.g. from myProcedure(int A=
, String B) to
test_myProcedure_int_A_String_B. The final goal would be to =
have the tool
comparing the class to the test_class and create stubs for ne=
w methods
while leaving the existing ones untouched.

Before I'm going to c=
reate it on my own, I wanted to know, if anybody knows
about an existing to=
ol, that does the job?

If it does not exist, is there a good reason, why t=
his automation wouldn't
make sense? Sometimes for complex function you may =
need several testcases,
but they can be easely created by taking the first =
stub and append a
number...

ail to:
